awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Ammonia Phase PARtitioning and Transport (APART)
awd_abstract_narration:
Atmospheric emissions of ammonia (NH3) contribute to the formation of fine particles and nitrogen deposition that affect human and ecological health, yet little is known about NH3 transformation and fate. In this project, the research team intends to perform airborne and ground-based measurements of NH3 emitted from major cattle and dairy feedlots in the foothills of the Rocky Mountain National Park (RMNP). Results will help inform atmospheric chemists and test a forecasting tool for the downwind transport of reduced nitrogen into a sensitive ecosystem. 

In this collaborative project between 2 institutions and 4 PIs, a 10-week field campaign is planned in the foothills of RMNP to determine (i) fluxes and deposition timescales of NH3 within 10 km downwind of large sources, and (ii) spatial distribution and partitioning of NHx ~100 km downwind of same sources. The main sampling platform is the University of Wyoming King Air (UWKA) research aircraft equipped with new measurement capabilities that allow for enhanced sampling strategies of gases and particulates. Gaseous species include reduced and oxidized nitrogen (NH3 and HNO3), methane (CH4), ethane (C2H6), carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2) and water vapor (H2O), while particulates include aerosol concentration and size and their water-soluble species concentrations. CH4 and C2H6 allow to track the plume and distinguish between different source types. Integration of flight data with ground-based observations collected from mobile monitoring and existing sampling sites, provides a means to better interpret consistently available ground-based data in the future. Results will also contribute to improved representation of NH3 in transport models, help predict local air quality and inform stakeholders. Two graduate and several undergraduate students will obtain valuable hands-on experiences in a collaborative field campaign.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ammonia contributes to fine particle formation and nitrogen deposition; however, less is known about the emissions, abundances, and loss processes for this species than other anthropogenic pollutants. In contrast to declining emissions of nitrogen oxides from combustion sources, the emissions of ammonia from fertilizer applications and livestock production have grown in the U.S. As a result, the deposition of reduced nitrogen in the U.S. has increased, and future progress in reducing nitrogen deposition will require reductions in emissions of ammonia from agricultural and nonagricultural sources. Optimizing policies around reduced nitrogen has necessitated increased study of atmospheric ammonia emissions, abundances, and loss processes. This project conducted airborne measurements of ammonia, aerosol composition, methane and ethane over Colorado using the University of Wyoming King Air (UWKA) research aircraft in August 2021 and August 2022. This work was conducted in the Colorado Front Range because there are large emissions sources of  ammonia from concentrated animal feeding operations in northeastern Colorado and abundant meteorological events to transport nitrogen-rich air to the sensitive ecosystems in Rocky Mountain National Park. 

The instrumented aircraft sampled the emissions from large concentrated animal feeding operations in Colorado, and it followed these plumes downwind to document their chemical evolution. In addition, the campaign captured the movement of nitrogen-rich airmassess from the polluted Colorado Front Range into the nearby Rocky Mountains. This data was used to calculate ammonia emissions ratios with respect to methane for a large set of feedlots and dairies in the region. The data shows larger emissions ratios than previously reported in the literature with a large range of values (i.e., 0.1–2.6 ppbv ppbv−1). Facilities housing cattle had a higher ratio than dairies. Only 15% of the total ammonia (particle + gas phases) was in the particle phase near major sources during the warm summertime months. The average summertime ammonia decay time to 80% and 60% against deposition in plumes from large animal sources is ~1 and ~2 hours, respectively. Ammonia emission rates from four optimally sampled facilities ranged from 4 to 29 g ammonia per hour per animal head. 

There are important commonalities in ammonia rich plumes that are transported into the Colorado Rocky Mountains during August. (1) Ammonia enhancements are present over the mountains on summer afternoons when easterly winds are present in the foothills region. (2) The abundance of gas-phase ammonia is 1 and 2 orders of magnitude higher than particle-phase ammonium over the mountains and major agricultural sources, respectively. (3) During thermally driven circulation periods, emissions from animal husbandry sources closer to the mountains likely contribute more to the ammonium observed over the mountains than sources located further east. (4) Transport of plumes from major animal husbandry sources in northeastern Colorado westward across the foothills requires ∼5 h. (5) Winds drive variability in the transport of ammonia into nearby mountain ecosystems, producing both direct plume transport and recirculation. These upslope ammonia transport events occur under very different conditions than those occurring in spring and later in the fall. A similar campaign in other seasons, including spring and autumn, when synoptic scale events can produce sustained upslope transport, would likely unveil differences in events occurring in these other seasons. Thermodynamic modeling to predict the seasonality of ammonium nitrate formation shows that during August, which is characterized by hot dry conditions, northeastern Colorado is consistently in the ammonia - rich and nitric acid - limited ammonium nitrate formation regime. Cooler temperatures could support substantially more ammonium nitrate formation.
